_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process storage tank, plumbing, transfer hose, liquid and vapor valves, hydrostatic relief valves, b
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Employees are trained (classroom and on the job) for the proper storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia at this facility as well as off site training provided by outside sources.  Written operating procedures for this facility are included in such training.
Prior to first use each season, equipment associated in the operations of Anhydrous Ammonia such as valves, pressure gauges, bleeder valves, percent capacity gauges, plumbing and dated materials including transfer hoses and relief valves are checked so as to be in proper operating condition.  This includes mobile equipment as well as facility storage tank.  Compliance audits and incident investigation reports will be documented and on file according to the RMP.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Facility Policy: The owners, management and employees of Paxton Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidental release  of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and law enforcement personnel to mitigate any release to residents and the environment  of our community.

2. Facility Information: The primary activity at the facility is the storage and
sales of fertilizers to farm producers in our area.

         a. Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop 
production nutrient.
b. The maximum quantity stored would be approximately 52,000 pounds in our 12,000 gallon
storage tank.  The maximum quantity  handled would be the unloading of a rail tank car holding
_

approximately 156,000 pounds.

~-

.
:

    
3. Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario:

a. The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of a rail tank car
released as a gas over 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be approximately
156,000 pounds which represents the volume of the rail tank car at 85 percent capacity as limited
by the design standards. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 1.18 miles.  
b. The alternative release scenario (most likely potential incident) is a release
from a break in a transfer hose. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is
.33 miles.

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program: The facility has implemented the provisions of
"Safety-Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published
by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U. S. Occupational
Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of
Anhydrous Ammonia".

5. Five-Year Accident History: There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in
the past five years tha

t have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the
facility, nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in
place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6. Emergency Response Program: Our facility has a written emergency response program in
accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.120 including pre-emergency planning and
employee training.


7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety: Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.
Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maineenance of safe conditions. At present, the
installation of 2 remote emergency shutoffs are planned to be installed on the plumbing of the
liquid lines that are used while unloading of a rail tank car.

8. For further information contact Roger Mullen, faciIity manager.

Roger Mullen
